body.h2: Proofreading Output for Inscriptions of Israel/Palestine
body.p: This page will show you the values you have encoded for inscription metadata and transcription, in a format that makes proofreading easier. Please make sure that your file is valid before proofreading. The proofreading script does not check for validity. Also, note that all items in the list below that are preceded by an asterisk (*) are required. If nothing shows up in the proofreading page, you should go back and check your xml file, and either add missing information or, if the information is there, make sure that it is encoded correctly.

*Title: Inscriptions of Israel/Palestine
*Machine-Readable (safe) Title: abil0001
*Human-Readable Title: Abil 0001

Contents (<msItem>):
*Main Language: arc [grc = Greek, la = Latin, heb = Hebrew ]
Other Languages:
*Genre (<class>): (#dedicatory)
*Religion (<ana>): ,
Summary: Golan Heights. Abilene, 70 CE - 500 CE. Lintel. Dedicatory.

Physical Description
*Type of Object <objectDesc>/@ana): lintel
*Type of Material (<supportDesc/@ana): stone
Details:
*Dimensions: Height - cm / Width - cm / Depth - cm
*Condition (@ana):
Condition Details:

Layout Description (Columns and Written Lines not required if not applicable. In that case, put info in the Details box)
*Columns: 1
*Written Lines: 5
Details

History
Origin:
*Date: 70 CE - 500 CE [NotBefore 0070 - NotAfter 0500]
Location:
*Region: Golan
*City: Abilene
*Site: synagogue
Locus:
Provenance:
PlaceName:

*Bibliography

Check Entries

Source of Commentary:

div.p:
דכיר ל[ט] [ - - - ] [ב]ר[ו(?)][ך] [ - - - ] ס̣ד̣ריי דהכה
[ד]אתחזק
[ב]דין תרעה
שלום
דכיר ל[ט] [ב]ר[ו(?)][ך] ס̣ד̣ריי דהכה [ד]אתחזק [ב]דין תרעה שלום
Remember for good Baruch [?] of Alexandria [?] who here gave and made this gate. Amen, peace.

The inscription was engraved on a cross-bar stone and discovered in a narrow street facing the church, which is located in the southern part of the village. The inscription and surrounding figures were found on the part of the stone that faces the street. There is a fracture at the top of the stone, which makes the beginning of the inscription difficult to read and required Barslavsky to fill in the blanks. The first line includes a well-known phrase which Barslavsky could easily recognize as "דכיר לטב" even though the ט and the ב were destroyed completely.
